reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening of 一.
The reading comes from 伺う.
You've learned both of these readings already. No fakes there.
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You've learned this reading already, so you should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
When you print something out, it's usually the paperwork needed in order to <reading>sue</reading> (す) someone. You're just that kind of person, always looking to sue.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned it when you learned 包む, but here's a reminder of the mnemonic just in case:

Remember how you wrap your <vocabulary>bundle</vocabulary>s? That's right, with the <reading>two two</reading> technique. Your <vocabulary>package</vocabulary>s are always double wrapped.

The reading for 即 is the normal one. For 日 you're going to want to use the じつ reading, because, the <reading>truth</reading> (じつ) is that it's the same day today.

The reading is the same as one of the readings you learned: ふう. Don't be a <reading>foo</reading>l, make sure you seal your envelopes.

The reading for the 御 is お because ふだ uses the kun'yomi reading. Kun'yomi + kun'yomi = yes.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm going <vocabulary>to console</vocabulary> you for what happened to you. The <reading>nag saw</reading> (なぐさ) was turned on and buzzed through your leg. What a nagging feeling. You need some consoling.

As a <reading>child</reading> (こ) you got a lot of chastising, I bet. A lot of learning by experience (of chastising).
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading for 戸 is an exception. Instead of と it's こ. Just think about how the person who runs this census doesn't care about number of toes. They care about number of <reading>子</reading> (こ).

Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 揚げる.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading is the same as the word 胸 (chest). So, the gist of your body is your chest (it's at the center, and holds everything together, right?). That's why these words are both read as <reading>むね</reading>.
What's especially delicious? <reading>Horse</reading> (うま) is delicious. Mmm, that delicious horse.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading for 暴 is strange and new, not what you learned with the kanji. Just think about how when there is disclosure or exposure of something, you are surprised. You can't believe that's the truth. You have to take a step <reading>back</reading> (ばく) to deal with the new information.
Of all the people who are bright and cheerful, one man comes to mind. The cheerful Hulk <reading>Hoga</reading>n (ほが).
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

You find something that is so <vocabulary>gentle</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>soft</vocabulary> to the touch. You touch it. You can't stop. The monkey you're touching tells you to stop. It doesn't like to be touched. But, you won't stop. "<reading>Yah wha</reading>t (やわ) you gonna do about it, monkey?" "<reading>Yah, wha</reading>t can I do, I guess," replies the monkey.

You didn't learn this reading of 柔 with the kanji, so let's remember it a different way. You have to be <vocabulary>gentle</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>tender</vocabulary> if you want to touch something that's <reading>new</reading> (にゅう) to this world... a puppy, a kitty, a baby, etc. Anything new needs that <vocabulary>gentleness</vocabulary>.

You look at the cow. Poor cow. <reading>She's</reading> (しず) sinking.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Oddly, this is the one word that uses the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. To remember this particular <vocabulary>swamp</vocabulary>, note how there are two kanji in here that make this area particularly swampy. Because it's the swampiest, boggiest place in all of Japan, of course the <reading>Sho</reading>gun (しょう) wants it for himself. Even though it's useless land, he wants the best of everything, being the Shogun and all.
The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

You are going <vocabulary>to destroy</vocabulary> the <reading>hoe roe</reading>. This is the roe that comes from the hoe tools. If they create too much roe, they will create too many hoes. And if there are too many hoes, bad things will happen.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

潜る has two possible readings: もぐる and くぐる. The first is used when you mean to dive underwater or go underground.  The second is used when you pass through or under something, sometimes with difficulty, such as crawling under a fence. We want you to focus on もぐる, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Why are you trying to dive underwater again and again? It's to get <reading>mo' goo</reading> (もぐ) to sell on the black goo market. Who knew that sea goo was such a commodity?

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: If you think of the tide, you think of the ocean. If you think of the ocean and what it's filled with (besides water) you think of <reading>salt</reading> (しお).
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This word is made up of the reading from 濡れる and the rendaku version of the きぬ reading of 衣. You learned this reading in the 衣 vocabulary, but here's a mnemonic to remember it. Imagine someone's dumped water on you and you're all wet. You might say "<reading>gi</reading>ve <reading>new</reading> (ぎぬ) clothes to me!"
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

With 草 you learned a different reading from the one here. Just think about how with this <vocabulary>pasture</vocabulary> you have to constantly <reading>sew</reading> (そう) it together to make it come together, otherwise it comes apart and moves all around, and that's no good for any pasture.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The secondary reading is a bit different. That's a family name, and uses the kun'yomi readings of both kanji. We'll consider this secondary for now, but you may have to come back to this when you see this as a name and are all like "what's going on here??"
The reading for this kanji is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. That in itself isn't too <vocabulary>rare</vocabulary>, wouldn't you say?

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You know what's <vocabulary>unusual</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>rare</vocabulary>? This <reading>maze</reading> is <reading>ra</reading>re (めずら). I don't think there's a way out of it. We've been walking around for days now, and we haven't gotten any closer to the exit!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
The reading is pretty weird, and not one you've learned. But, you know what sumo is, right? It's just the same as that. It's <reading>すもう</reading>.
The reading is the readings for 石 and 垣 combined into one word. Be careful of the rendakus.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: When it comes to <vocabulary>pipe</vocabulary>s, you always want to have two sets of two of them, just in case. So, that's a <reading>two two</reading> (つつ) set of pipes, lined up next to each other for backup.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading is a little different from 群れる, though. There's an extra ら in there. That being said, it's pretty similar, so you should be able to use one to remember the other after a few reps. You can also think about it this way: Everyone is flocking together in one place. Strange thing is, it's to a small <reading>村</reading> (むら). There's a 村 reunion going on, that's why.

In order to get it open, you need <vocabulary>to tear</vocabulary> and rip up a <reading>sack</reading> (さく). Sacks don't have tabs or zippers or any of those fancy things. If you want to get at the stuff in a sack you have to tear the top right off!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "You going <vocabulary>to attack</vocabulary> me or something? <reading>Oh so</reading> scary you are. Oh so scary. Ho ho ho."
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This shares the same reading as the vocabulary word 誠, but here's a reminder just in case:

<reading>My coat</reading> (まこと) <vocabulary>really</vocabulary> is a coat! <vocabulary>Indeed</vocabulary>, it is.

If something has <vocabulary>charm</vocabulary>, your thought/思 (おも) goes in that direction/向き (むき).  You feel the vibe? Do you get the gist?

This word uses the on'yomi readings for 軍 and 艦, and the kun'yomi reading for 島. You learned all of them, so you should know the reading already! Oh, but watch out for the rendaku.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: 

These houses that <vocabulary>stand in a row</vocabulary> are neat and fun to count, but you can't go in because you have <reading>no key</reading> (のき). With no key, those <vocabulary>eaves</vocabulary> are just there for you to look at.

This word uses the kun'yomi reading of the kanji, but you haven't learned it yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Dew</vocabulary> is just the earth's way of giving water <reading>to you</reading> (つゆ). Rain is too forceful, you may not go to the ocean or a lake, so the earth gives dew to you by putting it on the grass outside your house everyday!
